fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.bodyText: • An article about a service held to mark the centenary of Passchendaele said the family of John Ambrose Barrett, who was killed on the first day of the battle, believe he “never had the chance to meet his youngest child, Elsie, who was born in March 2017”. That should have been 1917 (‘It was still and misty and I could taste their blood in the air’, 1 August, page 10, early editions). • In Monday’s paper, an editorial about Brexit said the Passchendaele commemoration was being held in Mons. In fact it was held in Ypres (Who is running Brexit policy, Mrs May – you or the chancellor, 31 July, page 22). A feature about the battle said Ypres was known as “Leper to the Belgians”. The Belgian name for the city is Ieper (I died in hell - they called it Passchendaele, 31 July, page 1, early editions). And a letter misspelled the poet Ellis Humphrey Evans’s parents farm, Yr Ysgwrn, as Yr Ysgwyrn (The tragedies of Ypres remembered, 31 July, page 24). • Other recently corrected articles include: Israel refuses to remove metal detectors from mosque despite rising violence Gay bars and tarot cards: Liverpool show celebrates LGBT art
